page.title: 15Shurland Hall - Eastchurch
page.content: A feature of the{local history}is, Shurland Hall, ruins of a Tudor {mansion}situated on the outskirts of Eastchurch village. It is thought that there has been some sort of {building}on the site since Roman times. The present building was built by Sir Thomas Cheyne in the sixteenth century. In 1532 Henry VIIIth and his wife Anne Boleyn were guests at the Hall. During the{Second World War}Shurland Hall was occupied by the British Army when part of the rear of the building was destroyed following attacks by the Germans in the area. The last occupier of Shurland Hall was a man named Alexander Till whose tomb can be seen in All Saints Church, Eastchurch.
